title: About Corey
text:
Hello! I am Corey Williams, a master’s student in the statistics department at Oregon State University with a passion for high dimensional data and machine learning techniques. Outside of academics I enjoy many hobbies such as gaming, bouldering, and juggling.


Oregon State University | Corvallis, OR
M.S. in Statistics | August 2022 - Current
University of Idaho | Moscow, ID
B.S. in Mathematics & Statistics | January 2019 - December 2021



Oregon State University | Graduate Teaching Assistant | September 2022-Present
Oregon State University | Statistical Consulting Practicum | September 2023 - December 2023
University of Idaho | Statistics Assistance Center Tutor | March 2020-May 2022




Programming languages (In order of experience)

R, Python, SAS, C++, and SQL

Machine Learning

Random Forests, Support Vector Machines, Neural Networks, Principal Component Analysis, and K Means

Statistical Methods

Hypothesis testing, Linear Models, Generalized Linear models, Mixed Effect Models, Sampling Design, and Survey Design

Libraries/Modules

R: tidyverse, lme4, nlme, e1071, and randomForest
Python: TensorFlow, SciKit-Learn, NumPy, Pandas, and Matplotlib








Seely Award from Oregon State University





Chair’s Award for Excellence from the University of Idaho

title: Projects
text: This project’s purpose was for me to learn more about convolutional neural networks. I have been very interested in learning more about them and how to implement them so this was a great starting project.

title: Projects
text: another one

title: Projects
text: This project was completed for my mathematical biology class along with Alyssa Genther. This project looked at recreating the results of Dobay et. al. in Renaissance model of an epidemic with quarantine from the Journal of Theoretical Biology (2013). In addition to recreating some of the work in the paper we also looked at adding different lengths of quarantines at different time points. This work revolves around an SIR model framework.

title: Projects
section: Simulating Violations of Statistical Test Assumptions (December 2023)
text:
Simulating Violations of Statistical Test Assumptions (December 2023)
One of the areas I have seen students struggle with the most is in assessing the assumptions of statistical tests. I have found that students don’t really have any concept of what it looks like when assumptions are reasonably met and how far we can stretch assumptions while still getting useful results. (Heck even I still have a lot of room to improve in this!)
This project was created for my simulations and computation class and looked at violating the assumptions of equal variance and normality of t-tests and ANOVA.

title: Projects
section: Analysis of Quarantine Implementation in an Epidemic (May 2020)
text:
Analysis of Quarantine Implementation in an Epidemic (May 2020)
This project was completed for my mathematical biology class along with Alyssa Genther. This project looked at recreating the results of Dobay et. al. in Renaissance model of an epidemic with quarantine from the Journal of Theoretical Biology (2013). In addition to recreating some of the work in the paper we also looked at adding different lengths of quarantines at different time points. This work revolves around an SIR model framework.

title: Projects
text: This project’s purpose was for me to learn more about convolutional neural networks. I have been very interested in learning more about them and how to implement them so this was a great starting project.
